p: Vector–human contact rates are another important empirical gap in the mechanistic model, which could further refine the relationships between land use, human occupations and behaviour, and spillover risk. We approximate human contact rates with sylvatic vectors with per cent forest cover, but the relationship is likely much more complex. The surprising decreasing relationship between precipitation and spillover probability in the boosted regression tree ( figure 5 d) may be due to the influence of precipitation on human activities in and around forests, and therefore its influence on human–vector contact [ 96]. Additionally, while vector contacts depend on biting rate of the vector, and mosquito biting rates are known to depend on temperature for other species [ 107, 135], we assume constant biting rate in the mechanistic model owing to a lack of empirical evidence.
